I've been watching Crash Course since its beginnings and this has by far been my favorite series. Your team's ability to use the lens of Geography to create connections and implications that break the traditional siloing of disciplines while still remaining focused and devoted to a single topic has genuinely been awe-inspiring, no better word for it. As a future educator and fan of the show, thank you so much for this amazing series!!!! I can't wait to see what all of you do next!!
I always get emotional when a Crash Course series finishes. Thank you for all your fantastic content and DFTBA!

Thank you and the team for such an amazing series!

On the subject of, how much should the past be preserved, and how much should we push back against global homogenization, there's always going to be reflexive resistance to change, and just as reflexive dismissal of that rejection as childish and ignorant. Neither view is good, because they are unbalanced. Old doesn't mean obsolete. Traditional doesn't mean good. Innovative doesn't mean better. And new doesn't mean threat. The first, best thing to do is to never think there's a one-size-fits-all solution.
Ill miss you

My problem with these so called slow city movement initiatives is that how democratic these decisions are? I would argue that it is not enough for a city council or another body in charge to assume something like a "gravel road" is something that I need and would like to pay for through tax. For example, I like synthesizers and the 1980s gritty look, a others in my generation also respond well to that look, however it looks like only one specific vision of what a neighborhood should look like dominates everything and unless we the supposed 80s synthesizer group don't protest it rather aggressively (which we won't cause why bother, we are tired after work) have to live with. In short I argue that these movements are nothing but a committee presumption of what people like ....that's why you get radical movements to the opposite direction, since you have decided to decide for all of us.
One of my favorite Crash Course series. Loved every episode, I could watch 500 more. I've long had a fascination with maps and physical geography but this opened me up to so much more.
I am so sad the series is over loved every single episode

I can’t believe I was actually here for the start and end of a whole series. I’m truly saddened but I’m also so excited to see where this channel will go. I can’t wait for my kids to one day watch all these beautiful lessons that have taught me so much in such brief times. My wife’s major is geography, and what a wonderful little world of interwoven peoples from all over to bring these things together.  From my little corner of the world to yours, thanks for the memories.
